data.text: Whether you hit your daily goals or not will play out. You‚Äôve already triumphed. Celebrate the ride. If you don‚Äôt make your intended miles does that mean you failed? If you do, does that make your tour is a success? You sound pretty damn amazing and I am glad you didn‚Äôt loss your sense of joy and adventure with the trauma you experienced. I can‚Äôt imagine anything will be harder that what you have already been through. My only advice is that tours are organic experiences‚Äîthey are not a sum total of the miles and the terrain, but an expanding collage of landscapes, weather, mood, people , and a thousand other ingredients that combine into an imprint on your soul. It is great to challenge yourself and set hard goals‚Äîthey help us focus and give us motivation‚Äîbut it is easy for them to overwhelm what they were meant to prepare us for. The body is incredible. You know. You‚Äôve had to reteach it everything. What I have learned is that anxiety can decrease performance. We can talk ourselves into defeat. We can stress so much about achieving our goals that we almost convince ourselves that they are unattainable. I‚Äôll go back to my first point. If you don‚Äôt make the miles you wanted did that mean you failed? Some days you will hit your miles, some days you won‚Äôt. Some days you‚Äôll crush it and make more miles than you planned. What you don‚Äôt want to do is dread the days because you might fail. You triumph by leaving on your tour. By continuing to strive to be better. You‚Äôre riding that razor‚Äôs edge between prepared and stressed. Pull back a little. Remember that this is a celebration not a race.

data.text: Start out easy the first week or two. Do 50-60 miles max at the start. You will gain strength and endurance over time, but let your body (seat and arms get used to holding up your weight as you go). It more important to make certain you have good equipment, tires (spare also), tubes, tools any small repair parts (chain tool, links and a short section of chain), a few spokes and zip ties. If you breakdown on the road you want to be able to repair to get to next town. If you're going W2E, work on hills with a test load to get used to climbing and handling the load. I did a 4,400 mile 11 week your and we started in IN and by the time we hit the Rockies, we had 4-5 weeks of riding, E2W does have it's advantages. Double check what you think you need vs. what you really need. You don't want to wait until you into your trip to find you've packed too much weight.

data.text: as I am getting older, I notice my hands get cold faster, and I also hate very much to have cold hands. So now packing warm gloves is a very important priority. I don't recommend to get your chest cold, but it can happen - if it happens, try to find some paper. Newspaper or wrapping paper or whatever. Make balls out of it and stuff it inside your jersey. The insulation will keep you warm. I've used this more than once. One time when my kid was a baby and I forgot to pack his jacket, I stuffed spare diapers in his clothes with the same insulation idea.
